Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Scots Science Scholars (S^3) program is a four-year program designed to increase retention and graduation rates of underrepresented and first generation students in STEM majors at Maryville College in Tennessee. The program includes three vital components designed to retain students in STEM fields to graduation. (1) The summer bridge program coordinates lab work with mathematical content and emphasizes discovery learning to prepare students for college-level STEM work. (2) The specialized first-year curriculum is designed to build community and provide academic support for the students through common coursework in STEM disciplines. In particular, the orientation course includes strategies for success in college level STEM courses, field trips and guest speakers related to STEM disciplines. (3) The research/leadership experience begins in the first year and is integrated with the Maryville College core curriculum through experiential education and the capstone senior study project. Student participants build leadership skills by acting as mentors, spokespersons and role models for incoming S^3 students.

This program reveals the impact of such efforts on retention of students from underrepresented groups in STEM majors at a small, liberal arts college with a majority white population. It also clarifies the significant effects of a bridge program and undergraduate research separate from the extra attention and mentoring student participants receive in similar programs at large universities, since these are part of the Maryville College experience for all students. S^3 informs the implementation of similar programs at other small liberal arts colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scots Science Scholars (S3 ) program at Maryville College (MC) began in 2013 and has made a positive impact on STEM retention and success at Maryville College through enrichment and support for select students and programming for the wider college commuity.  

Targeting promising high school students who indicate interest in STEM majors, the program begins with a summer experience before their first year of college. Students spend time in science and computing labs, visit STEM professionals at Oak Ridge National Laboratories and Tennessee Valley Authority, and participate in team-building experiences and early research. This provides them with a connection to the STEM professions and a strong support group that they can depend on in their first semester and throughout their college careers.  Some of the students continue to be involved in research projects starting in their first or second year and have presented at regional and national conferences.  Throughout the school year the program offers all participants ongoing academic support in the form of the STEM success center that is staffed by a student support specialist and peer tutors.  The final component of the program is a STEM event series that is open to all students that includes designed to show students a variety of STEM career options.

Every one of the 97 students who has enrolled in the program has participated in a research project at some level, contributing to nine different research projects that resulted in 20 different presentations at academic conferences and one peer reviewed publication. The STEM event series has hosted 37 presentations by STEM employers, young alumni in STEM fields, graduate school representatives and current MC students who have completed summer research or internships.   During the grant period, over 300 different students have attended.  The STEM Success Center is open five nights a week and provides academic support in the form of tutoring and mentoring as well as skill development.  The center has provided thousands of hours of support to over 50 students in the last 3 years.

The program has increased retention in STEM majors. Students who participate in the program are over three times more likely to retain as a STEM major to the sophomore year and twice as likely to retain at any other point. S3 has erased differences in retention between students of differing economic backgrounds. Participants who come from high financial need backgrounds are retained at the same rate as those from and low financial need backgrounds, increasing success for students who are traditionally at risk for leaving STEM majors.  Additionally, along with other factors, S3  has contributed to a 52% increase in the number of STEM majors at MC over the last 5 years.  The Scots Science Scholars are a visible part of the MC community, volunteering at STEM outreach and recruiting events and participating in student life.  Due to the success of the program, the administration has agreed to continue funding the program.  S3 may serve as a model for programming at other small, liberal arts schools increasing access to, and success in STEM majors for students from varying backgrounds.
